column10: I thought it was fun, but it gave my girlfriend motion sickness. If you want a fun, casual multiplayer puzzle game, this is pretty good, unless you're sensitive to simulated motion in a 3D environment.

Game was mostly to the point. But had just enough ground clutter to not make it a simple solve every time.
Controls are a bit difficult to comprehend for people fresh to gaming such as my wife, but manageable.
Textures are very flat but that also makes it easier to understand what is in the room as it hard(er) to hide parts.
Music is nothing fantastic but not annoying. 
The only annoyance so far is that they did NOT explain certain KEY control elements. Such as how to pick up a part and make it so you can drag and drop other parts on it. ANd how to "pin" things so it does not zoop back into your inventory. They did have a "Tutorial" level. But these mechanics are not in the Tutorial and was critical to solve several puzzles.
A bit pricey for the content. But if you manage to catch this on sale and have another player, it is many hours of good puzzles.

Escape Simulator has endless content. The workshop is robust and there are amazing creators who have created a number of amazing rooms. 

There is constantly new DLC coming out for very affordable prices and we're often surprised with seasonal, free dlc that is always a joy.

If you're looking for something that will keep you distracted in short spurts, this is it. If you're looking for a casual game to play for hours on end, this is it. And if you're looking for something to play with friends or a partner, this is it!

Escape Simulator has proven to be an excellent game choice for engaging and stimulating minds, particularly when I played it while babysitting Caleb, a family friend with autism. Its puzzles offer just the right balance of challenge and achievability, promoting logical thinking and problem-solving skills in a fun, immersive environment. The structured nature of the escape rooms, with clear goals and systematic solutions, caters well to autistic individuals who thrive on order and predictability. Caleb was particularly drawn to the game's interactive elements and the satisfaction of solving puzzles, which boosted his confidence and kept him engaged for hours. The game's visually appealing design and intuitive gameplay make it accessible, reducing frustration and ensuring a positive experience. Additionally, Escape Simulator's cooperative mode encouraged social interaction in a controlled setting, enhancing Caleb's communication skills in a comfortable and enjoyable way. Overall, Escape Simulator is not just entertaining; it's a valuable tool for cognitive development and social learning, making it a perfect fit for children like Caleb.

Escape Simulator is an online cooperative game where you and up to three other people try to solve puzzles together and uncover collectibles. 

PROS: 
+ Cooperative gameplay.
+ Cartoony graphics that're pleasing to the eye.
+ Lots of rooms made by developer (and more coming out for FREE!).
+ Rooms have different themes, ranging from Ancient Egyptian to Victorian mansions to futuristic space stations. 
+ Public and private gaming.
+ Male and female characters, where you can choose clothing, hair style, skin color, hair color, etc.
+ Workshop integration from the start (with a bunch of player-made rooms).
+ Developer-made rooms are generally small, which cuts down on motion sickness.
+ Options included in-game to deal with motion sickness.
+ Room editor is relatively simple to use and relies on a tile-based grid system.
+ Time limit is purely for achievements and you can completely ignore it if you wish.
+ Relatively low system requirements for a game released in 2021.
+ Will run on older operating systems like Windows 7 or Win 8/8.1, and is compatible with Mac OS and Linux.
+ Steam Cloud

NEUTRAL:
+/- Time limit might annoy some players who feel as if they need to complete the room before time is up, despite the time meaning nothing beyond achievements.
+/- Community-made rooms in the Workshop can vary greatly in quality (although this is through no fault of the developer).

CONS:
- Escape Simulator is only really fun when playing alongside at least one other person, which might make this game difficult to play if you have to rely on random players online. 
- Tokens are sometimes hidden in locations that are nearly impossible to see or get to, although the most recent developer-made rooms have been fixing that. 
- Game engine isn't designed (or at least optimized) for large rooms because some larger community-made rooms can cause a significant drop in framerate. 
- Very limited character customization, but at least character customization exists at all. In many Escape Room games you can't even make a character and instead you're essentially a "floating head." 
- While most of the graphics in the game are quite nice, there are some startling low textures on some (but not all!) carpets and other pieces of furniture.

VERDICT: Escape Simulator is a fun game to play alongside friends or family (my wife is my co-op partner), and is probably the best escape room game we've come across on Steam up to this point. The developers have done everything they can to mitigate motion sickness (which is a real problem for some people, my wife included) and make the game as user-friendly as possible while giving people tools to be creative. 

The only drawback I can really see to this game is that while you don't technically need other players (as specified earlier, you can play single player), Escape Simulator would feel empty or lifeless without other real people involved. So for gamers who don't have readily available co-op partners, grouping with randoms is really the only alternative and in my experience that's a real crapshoot. 

That said... if you have at least one co-op partner and you enjoy escape rooms (and puzzles in general), I'd strongly recommend Escape Simulator. It's a great non-combative, stress-free alternative to the vast majority of games out there.

Escape Simulator has been an absolute blast to play! As someone who enjoys this new genre of puzzle games, I found myself completely immersed in the challenging yet immensely satisfying gameplay that this title offers.

From the moment I entered the first room, I was hooked. The intricately designed puzzles, cleverly hidden clues, and unexpected twists kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire experience. Each room presented a unique set of challenges that required both logic and creativity to overcome, making every escape attempt a thrilling adventure.

What sets Escape Simulator apart is its attention to detail and immersive atmosphere. The environments are richly detailed, with interactive objects and subtle hints scattered throughout. The sound design further enhances the experience, adding tension and suspense as you race against the clock to solve each puzzle and unlock the next door.

But perhaps the most satisfying aspect of Escape Simulator is the sense of accomplishment that comes with each successful escape. The feeling of cracking a particularly tricky puzzle or uncovering a hidden passage is immensely gratifying, and it's what kept me coming back for more.

In conclusion, Escape Simulator is a must-play for fans of puzzle-solving and escape room experiences. It's a testament to the ingenuity of indie developers and the limitless potential of the genre. If you're looking for a game that will challenge your wits and keep you entertained for hours on end, look no further than Escape Simulator. Trust me, you won't be disappointed!

Lots of fun if you are looking to feed your escape room fix.

I love puzzle games and I wanted to play co-op with my friend, so we tried this out. I wish there was a 'mixed feelings' review instead of a yes/no, but I have to say I'm leaning to 'no'. 

Pros: 
- Victorian themed rooms were fun and intuitive 
- A decent amount of content 

Cons: 
- Buggy asf. We didn't trophy a room because one of the puzzles required us to put ingredients in the fire in order, and the second ingredient floated in the fire instead of burning. We had to do it 3 times before it registered.
- Battery in a space room kept glitching in and out through the floor.
- Items dropped out of bounds usually respawn in the middle of the room, but some items can get stuck at an angle with an invisible wall (Egypt top of pyramid room). Had to keep throwing an object at it to try and knock it out of bounds so it could respawn. 
- The controls are clunky. 
- Can't share item inventory, and trying to read a page with a friend makes the item drop. 
- Big items in the room can't be thrown into the trash can and end up getting in the way. A LOT.

It‚Äôs an escape room. If you‚Äôre unfamiliar: You‚Äôre locked in a room and need to solve puzzles to get the key to escape. There are many levels and the puzzles are incredibly varied (much to my surprise ‚Äì I thought they were bound to repeat themselves after the second room).

If you‚Äôre thinking of Escape from Monkey Island, think again: All the puzzles make sense, and even if you need a hint to get the solution, you‚Äôll slap your head because all the hints were really right in front of your eyes the whole time. Talking about the hint system: That‚Äôs great, too, and doesn‚Äôt just give you the solution right away.

If you like escape rooms, do get this game. It‚Äôs worth the full prize, especially with all the free updates Pine Studios provides.

As much as I adore escape rooms and puzzles, this game just doesn't deliver nearly as much as I wish it would.

The game actively encourages you to explore the rooms. That's great, because you're obviously not going to be finding everything you need by staying in one spot. Open drawers, sift through files, tinker with stuff. It's like any escape room, right?

Well...

The rooms themselves are VERY small. Sometimes you'll be vying for space with the remains of a broken urn, or maybe a chest lid that can't be removed from the room at all. While you can toss unneeded items and trash into the trash can in every room, it still doesn't  solve the issue of, say, three wood beams that somehow fell during the solving of a puzzle. That's not including the sheer number of bloat items in every level, designed to either get in your way, draw your attention away from a puzzle, or act as red herrings.

The game also has a number of optional goals that can be completed as you play. These come in the form of timed completion and tokens. Tokens are hidden in every room of the base game, eight per room. As far as I know, they don't do anything for you except contribute toward an achievement, but some of the tokens are either hidden in places you'll likely never look, or are IMPOSSIBLE to get if you finish the room. Timed completions net you a fancy trophy symbol on the level menu, as well as an achievement, but I personally find the presence of a timer stress-inducing. That being said, you can go back and replay levels as much as you want, so knowledge of the map will let you beat the clock if you're into that sort of thing.

Anyway, back to the game. The game doesn't take long to throw some incredibly vague environmental hints your way. For folks who like a challenge, this might not be that big of a deal, but when I say vague, I mean VAGUE. That's not even mentioning the sheer number of puzzles where the hints are almost non-existent. Even things that seem to be straightforward and very clearly correct are just...WRONG? 

Seriously, the game gaslights you into thinking you're stupid or doing something wrong. An obvious answer based on the hints you have just doesn't work, but through some mental gymnastics and mysticism you were SUPPOSED to arrive at THIS answer. I'm not sure who thought these puzzles were acceptable, but so many of the solutions to these puzzles are either convoluted or require knowledge that you DON'T have any access to at all ANYWHERE in the room. Two words: Chinese Takeout. If you played far enough, you'll know what that means. So many puzzles led to me dropping my Steam Deck onto my bed and pulling out my phone to look up the answer, which is NOT some thing you want players doing.

"But you could have just used the hints!" someone might be saying. That's true, random netizen. The game does give a hint button, and there's no real disadvantage to hitting that sucker if you need the help. Which is nice, because I feel like some people will be HAMMERING that button just to get through some of the later rooms. But remember what I said about some of the game's hints: They're vague. And I mean VAGUE. I'm repeating that again, because some of the hints just didn't explain anything, while others just straight-up gave the answer. A good hint gives you a nudge in the right direction. It doesn't slap you and say "You do this you idiot." 

All that being said: SOME of the rooms were really well-designed, to the point of not needing the hints, AND to the point of actually being a lot of fun. The second themed area in the base game is an EXCELLENT example of good design. It was a great balance of challenging and fun, with a lot of moments where I would go "Oh, that's clever!", or had me laughing to myself and thinking "You thought could fool ME?". THAT is the stuff I live for. It also took me back to my time with The Room, which...gods, I miss that series. 

That set of rooms was the only one where I wasn't feeling as if the game was trying to make me feel stupid. Clever hiding places, clearly marked points of interest, well-designed environmental hints that you might gloss over at first until your brain goes "Wait, turn back, what'd I see?"...If the game had consisted of rooms of that nature, I wouldn't be writing this. I'd be GUSHING about how much I love this game instead.

Of course, I'd be doing a disservice if I neglected to talk about the player-made rooms. Yes, you can make your own torture room for others to fail at, too, and, yes, some of the people who make them are absolutely insane. But, more importantly, some of the creators have nailed a great balance of challenge and fun. If the game's basic rooms are making you want to pull your hair out with how difficult they can be, give some of the workshop rooms a go. 

Tl;DR - Game is okay for those who really REALLY love escape rooms, but suffers from issues related mainly to puzzle difficulty and room size. Workshop levels are great, but the game is better picked up while on sale rather than at full price.

First thing, this and Escape Academy have barely anything to do with each other: both are good games, but while Escape Academy relies on plot and story telling, Escape Simulator relies more on being an experience of thinking and puzzle solving.
And I must admit, each puzzle has a great ambiance, which provides a good background while solving them. 

If you're a fan of puzzle solving, go for it and its DLCs. It's a very good way to spend time solving puzzles without a story in between, when you feel like you just want to keep your mind occupied.

Also, get the soundtrack if you can. I was amazed the first time I heard "Rainy Night". Such a sad, yet calming piece.

I am having a blast with Escape Simulator!  The rooms are all just enough of a challenge without being so hard I want to give up.  The tokens make each room re-playable.  I've played solo and I've teamed up with the friend who introduced me to escape rooms.  Both ways are enjoyable and if I'm having trouble with a puzzle, teaming up is a surefire way to work through it.  I love that there are community designed rooms, though I haven't had a chance to play those yet.  Something to look forward to.  I liked the fact that I could demo the game to see if I liked it (and that co-op mode worked in the demo).  The demo was just enough of a taste that I was sold on it.

As for things that I don't like... I usually have to start the game, close it and restart it because it's always glitchy the first time it loads up.  That may be due to my PC, though.  We haven't had to use many hints, but when we did they were a mix of helpful and not really helpful at all (and the community rooms don't have them).

I don't play a lot of video games because they are hard on my hands, but this is one I can definitely play.  If you enjoy puzzles, mind games, and real-life escape rooms, you should definitely try out the free demo to see if this is something you'll enjoy.

My initial review (above) was afetr playing 12.3 hours.  I have now played an additional 191 hours.  I've played about 157 rooms, including all the Pine rooms as well as well over 100 community rooms, and I love them all.  There are amazing room builders in this community, designing excellent and intriguing rooms for us to play.  I did try building a room early on, but had some trouble and gave up.  I'd like to give it another try in the future.

I absolutely recommend Escape Simulator to anyone who enjoys puzzle games and in-person escape rooms.

Escape Simulator, along with its DLCs, offers a phenomenal cooperative gaming experience that strikes the perfect balance between challenge and enjoyment. The puzzles are thoughtfully designed, offering just the right level of difficulty to keep you intrigued without veering into frustratingly illogical territory. Each puzzle feels solvable with the clues provided, making the experience both satisfying and intellectually stimulating.

A standout feature is the game's embrace of community creativity. The in-game editor and map maker are fantastic additions, empowering players to craft their own puzzles and share them with the community. This not only keeps the game fresh but also fosters a sense of connection and collaboration among players.

Additionally, the developers' monthly selection of community maps adds a curated touch, ensuring that players have access to high-quality, player-created challenges. This aspect of the game enriches the experience, as it consistently introduces new and exciting puzzles to solve.

Whether you're playing solo or with friends, Escape Simulator is a game I highly recommend. Its blend of engaging puzzles, community involvement, and developer support creates a dynamic and enjoyable environment that's hard to beat.

Escaped My Responsibilities... in the Game, Not Real Life

Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

Have you ever wanted to escape from your mundane life, but the closest you've gotten is hiding in the bathroom with your phone? Well, fear not, because Escape Simulator is here to fulfil your wildest escape fantasies without the risk of your boss finding you curled up behind the office plant!

This game is the Houdini of virtual escapes. I felt like a genius solving puzzles, unlocking doors, and avoiding obstacles, all from the comfort of my sweatpants. It turns out, my superior intellect is only hindered by the lack of secret passages in my apartment.

The graphics are so realistic that I almost called my landlord to complain about the broken light in the game. Sorry, Gary, it's just pixels. And speaking of realism, the sound effects are so immersive that I had to check if my cat was meowing in the game or in real life. Note: It was both. Apparently, my cat is an escape artist too.

The best part is the character customization. I gave my virtual self a ninja costume, because nothing says "stealthy escape" like a ninja doing the moonwalk. Take that, surveillance cameras!

The only downside is that after playing this game, I tried to use a crowbar to open my front door. Now my neighbors think I'm auditioning for a superhero role. Thanks, Escape Simulator, for turning me into the neighborhood weirdo. At least I can escape judgment in the game.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game that lets you escape reality without actually quitting your job or leaving your house, Escape Simulator is the key to your digital getaway. Just be prepared to explain to your friends why you're practicing lock-picking skills on your bedroom door.

You could play this game for the built-in escape rooms - and you should, they're quite good.

You could play this game for the DLC escape rooms - and you should, they're quite good.

But you should definitely play this game for the community-built rooms. Even as of this review, two years and change, people are still creating inventive rooms and puzzles and stories and the dev team is still highlighting their own favorites every month. That's the sign of a good game - not even the quality of the game itself, but the quality of the content the community builds around it.
Great game for fans of puzzles or escape rooms!
This is a great game to play with friends, and something that (as someone who loves physical escape rooms) satisfies that urge to go to an escape room.

It's such a fun game to play with friends, and there are plenty of levels you can play single-player as well. The community levels are creative and it's amazing to see what people create. I would definitely recommend for those who love escape rooms, but don't love the associated price tag or just straight up can't afford to go often.

Escape Simulator is a great game, but it desperately needs the community workshop to make it viable.

By it's very nature, Escape Rooms don't really have any replay value, so it's exceptionally easy to burn through all the official maps quickly. The workshop maps made by the community are thankfully plentiful, though some are definitely better than others. The fact that the creators continue to release new updates even years after release definitely adds value too.

My two biggest dislikes with the game are the very basic, plastic-y rendering models (though that does make community creations much easier to craft and therefore more accessible), and the complete lack of save; you have to complete the entire room or start over from scratch; no pausing or stepping away in the middle of a room when something urgent comes up. (Timers in games are my arch-nemesis.)

I'm also not in love about the control scheme and the in-game object interactions; even after dozens of hours and many rooms, it's still counter-intuitive and I have to think about the buttons I'm pressing or where I'm clicking to get the result I want. It's also sometimes difficult to tell if you're just faffing about, or actually holding an object in the correct place to get a desired interaction.


So do I recommend the game? Yeah, yeah I do. The price tag (even without a sale) is low enough that buying copies for your friends to play with you won't break the bank, and the community workshop keeps the game fresh even after hours of playing. But it is by no means a perfect slam dunk, and there's absolutely room for UI improvement.

If you wanted a good co-op (or solo) puzzle game, this does the trick quite nicely.
The puzzles are extremely varied and plentiful both in theme and execution, and they've continued to add free content for some time alongside DLC. Plus the game isn't punishing; if you get stuck you always have the hint button (which seem to have no penalty).

I got about 11-12 hours out of the base game with the base and free added content combined (including the just-added portal content), which I think is well worth the price. There's also community created rooms, and it currently doesn't seem like there is much of a limit to what you can do on that end of things.

I definitely recommend it.

This game is a hidden gem and a half. It's a labor of love that gets free updates all the time, it's incredibly fairly priced, and the modding / workshop community is out of this world in creating some of the most fun and creative escape rooms I've ever seen. If you're even half a fan of puzzle games or escape rooms, you're missing out if you don't pick this up.

Escape Simulator: Unlocking the Fun

Escape Simulator is a game that's all about breaking free from the mundane and challenging your mind to its limits. Here's a concise breakdown of what makes it an engaging experience:

üñ•Ô∏è Graphics: A Beautiful World

The game boasts visuals that are not just good but downright beautiful. It immerses you in its world and provides an enticing backdrop for your escape challenges.

‚ú® Gameplay: A Truly Captivating Experience

Escape Simulator offers a gaming experience that goes beyond the ordinary. It's not just very good; it's captivating and enthralling. Each escape presents a puzzle waiting to be unlocked, making every moment enjoyable.

üéµ Audio: Setting the Tone Right

The audio complements the game effectively, making your escape journey more immersive and engaging. It's not just good; it sets the right tone for the challenge at hand.

üë™ Audience: Teens and Adults Welcome

Escape Simulator caters to a slightly more mature audience, making it suitable for both teens and adults who are ready to put their minds to the test.

üñ•Ô∏è PC Requirements: Accessible to Many

The game doesn't demand a supercomputer; it runs on decent PC specs. This accessibility ensures that a broad range of players can enjoy the escape experience.

üß† Difficulty: Unleash Your Brainpower

Prepare to put your thinking cap on as Escape Simulator calls for significant brain usage. It's challenging, requiring logical thinking and creative problem-solving.

üÜô Grind: Leaderboards Await

If you're the competitive type, there's a grind involved in achieving the top spots on leaderboards. Otherwise, it's optional and doesn't hinder your progress.

üìñ Story: A Dash of Lore

While it's not a story-driven game, Escape Simulator provides a sprinkle of lore to keep you engaged. It's more than just puzzles; there's an underlying narrative to explore.

‚åõ Game Time: A Satisfying Average

The game's length is just right, neither too short nor too long. It provides a satisfying escape adventure without overwhelming you.

üí∞ Price: Worth Every Penny

For those seeking a challenging escape experience, Escape Simulator is worth the price. It's a rewarding investment for puzzle enthusiasts.

üêû Bugs: A Smooth Escape

You can embark on your escape missions without worrying about bugs. The game maintains a level of stability that ensures a smooth escape journey.

üèÜ Verdict: A Perfect 10 for Escapers

Escape Simulator truly shines as an engaging puzzle game. If you're a fan of brain-teasers and captivating challenges, this one deserves a solid 10 in your gaming library.

[h1] Escape Simulator: The Ultimate Puzzle Adventure with Friends [/h1]

Imagine the thrill of escape rooms, but in a digital realm. Escape Simulator by Pine Studio makes it a reality. With 16 themed escape rooms, it offers a delightful experience for you and your friends.

The game keeps it fresh with three themes for its rooms: ancient Egypt, spaceship adventures, and classic manor mysteries. Each theme brings unique twists to the puzzles, ensuring that no two rooms feel the same.

You navigate 3D rooms, similar to a point-and-click puzzler like The Room. It allows you to pick up, examine, and interact with items to uncover clues. However, be careful not to clutter the room, as a helpful bin allows you to store unwanted items. The game's art style, reminiscent of Planet Coaster, makes it clear which items are essential for solving puzzles. No more random clicking and hoping for the best.

Escape Simulator thrives when played with friends. You can team up with up to four players in each room. Much like real escape rooms, it's an excellent opportunity to bond or engage in friendly arguments over puzzle solutions. The game often offers multiple puzzles to work on simultaneously, so there's no downtime. Plus, you can see each other's cursors, enhancing collaboration.

After conquering all the rooms, the game provides collectibles and speedrunning as additional challenges. Tokens hidden within each room offer extra objectives. Completing rooms within a 15-minute time frame is another challenge, with rewards for successful speedruns.

One of Escape Simulator's standout features is its user-generated content. The game includes a robust content creation tool, allowing players to craft their own escape rooms. Shared via the Steam Workshop, this feature has the potential to extend the game's replayability indefinitely. With a growing library of custom user content, Escape Simulator offers endless possibilities for puzzle enthusiasts.

Get ready for an exciting puzzle adventure with friends in Escape Simulator!

TLDR:
 Escape Simulator is a well-made and immersive puzzle game that captures the essence of real-life escape rooms. With its emphasis on puzzles and cooperative gameplay, it offers a unique experience for players. 

The game's official levels are well-designed and visually appealing, with each environment having its own distinct theme. The inclusion of a hint system helps players when they get stuck, although there are instances where it could be more effective. The game's community-made levels provide endless content and creativity, allowing players to enjoy a wide variety of puzzles and challenges. 

The level editor is a powerful tool that opens up possibilities for players to create their own rooms and share them with others. While the game lacks midgame saving and VR support, its strengths in puzzle design and cooperative play make it a highly enjoyable experience. Whether playing solo or with friends, Escape Simulator is a must-play for puzzle enthusiasts and offers long-lasting entertainment.

Escape Simulator is a true masterpiece puzzle gaming. From start to finish, this game had me hooked, and I couldn't get enough of its challenging puzzles, immersive atmosphere, and cleverly designed escape scenarios. It's easy to see why Escape Simulator deserves a solid 5/5 stars.

What sets Escape Simulator apart from many other escape room games is its intuitive controls and user-friendly interface. Navigating the game is a breeze, allowing you to focus on the puzzles without being hindered by clunky mechanics. The hints system is also a great addition, providing just the right amount of help when you need it without giving away the solution.

In conclusion, Escape Simulator is a must-play for anyone who enjoys escape room games, puzzles, or immersive adventures. Its stunning visuals, challenging puzzles, and seamless gameplay make it a standout title in the genre. With a variety of escape scenarios and the option to play with friends, it offers hours of entertainment and replayability. Escape Simulator is a true 5/5 star experience that will keep you engaged and entertained from beginning to end. Don't miss out on this thrilling escape adventure!

The game aint devoid of fun. I as a seasoned computer games saw this kind of gameplay dozens of times already, but my wife who never played a game in her life likes it.
I cannot recommend this game for two reasons though:

1) I bought this game for co-op, to have good time with my wife, and that was why I had to buy two copies of the game. But there's no co-op in this game actually. I mean you can play co-op, but all the puzzles are solvable if you're playing alone. Even worse: you can't solve puzzles together in this game. That's right, so your co-op will go like that: you stand in the opposite sides of the room and solve your own puzzle each. Or the one of you who is more skilled is running around the room and solving all the puzzles etc while another struggles to find anything to do. During the first 3 rooms of Egypt there was only one instance of working together: we had to pull 2 levers at the same time. Only once, that's it. If it changes a lot later, which I doubt, I will change my opinion.

2) There's no Russian translation of this game. Yes, 2nd (or 3rd, but still) most spoken language on the Internet is ignored by the developers. I cannot explain it other than it's a political statement. If so, then the developers better know that Russian is a language that Ukrainian people look for on Steam as well as Russians etc. The game turns 2 soon, it has Turkish, Italian (which I don't mind in the slightest)... requests from Russian-speaking community is ignored. While I've not yet dug into the Room Creator options myself, Escape Simulator's prepackaged Escape Rooms are quite worth the value of the game.  Once you start digging into the Creator-uploaded rooms, this particular Steam gem really shines.  Sure, there are rooms uploaded that are lackluster, but for less than the price of a single real-life escape room, you have dozens of well-crafted default rooms as well as hundreds of challenging and beautiful player-submitted rooms to entertain you.  Seriously one of the absolute best gaming "investments" I've ever made.  I'm eventually going to have to get a VR setup, because this game in VR is going to be SMASHING.  If you haven't already picked this absolute gem up...don't hesitate, especially if you legitimately enjoy the escape room experience.  No better value exists in that regard, at least not yet!

Kudos, devs, on creating a genuinely timeless masterpiece of creative gaming!

This one is slightly too difficult for me as I need to rely on the hints more that I'd like to. I have managed to solve some rooms, but this game will take me some time to finish. That's not a bad thing, but I suspect it might get frustrating at some point. I like that you can pick up so much stuff that has nothing to do with solving the room, so what you need to use isn't that obvious. Also, it's nice that all rooms are available at once without needing to solve the earlier ones first, so you won't get stuck, if you can't solve something right away.

Edit: I have now played all the main rooms and all but one of the extras. Some rooms were really tricky and I needed to find a walkthrough to figure out how some puzzles worked. Still, I've enjoyed this game so much that I decided to buy the DLCs as well. One thing I forgot to mention in my original review is that there is a timer, which I thought was a bummer at first, but it's actually just tied to the achievements, you can use as much time as you need to, if you don't care about those.

Fun game!

The rooms that other players make for the workshop is the true hidden gem of this game. While the developer's rooms are of the highest quality in terms of overall puzzle design and functionality, the shear amount of escape rooms available through Steam Workshop is insane.

Sure, there are lots of simple rooms that look like someone spent an hour on, but there are ones that really stand out that are DLC-worthy quality (in some rare cases, even better) and they're all free. Every week there's at least 4-5 new very enjoyable rooms made by a thriving community of room designers so the game always feels pretty fresh.

Developer is actively working on updates all the time and releasing new paid and free DLC so there's always something to look forward to. I remember the game took a little getting used to because your movement is a bit limited (for instance you can't jump) and the inventory/slotting really needs more polish (even still), and having watched my girlfriend play it I can tell there's a small learning curve with managing items.

If you like escape rooms and puzzle solving, this is the game to get (even at full price, which is a steal IMO). Other escape room games are at most 2-3 rooms and they're all over in an hour or two. Play through the main/DLC rooms first before you dive into the 100+ high quality workshop rooms.

Recommended: Yes

Playtime: 6.1 Hours

Achievement Completion: 100%

Game Length: 7-10 Hours

Reviewed on: PC

Pros:
1. Immersive Puzzles: Escape Simulator offers a diverse range of challenging puzzles that require both critical thinking and keen observation skills. The variety ensures that gameplay remains engaging throughout.
2. Realistic Environments: The game excels in creating realistic escape room environments, with attention to detail that enhances immersion. From dimly lit chambers to cluttered offices, each scenario feels authentic.
3. Smooth Controls: The intuitive controls make interacting with objects and solving puzzles a seamless experience. There's a natural flow to the gameplay, allowing players to focus on the challenges at hand.
4. Cooperative Gameplay: The option for multiplayer adds an exciting dynamic. Collaborating with friends or strangers adds an extra layer of complexity to the puzzles and encourages teamwork.
5. Regular Updates: The developers have shown a commitment to the game's longevity by consistently releasing new rooms and scenarios. This keeps the content fresh and provides ongoing challenges for players.

Cons:
1. Limited Story Integration: While the focus is on the puzzles, some players may feel a lack of a cohesive narrative. A stronger storyline could add depth to the overall experience.
2. Occasional Technical Hiccups: There were infrequent instances of minor glitches, such as objects not responding as expected. However, these were relatively rare and didn't significantly impact gameplay.
3. Learning Curve for New Players: Those unfamiliar with escape room mechanics might find the initial learning curve steep. A more comprehensive tutorial or optional hints could be beneficial for beginners.
4. Room Diversity: While the environments are well-crafted, a bit more variety in the types of rooms and scenarios would add further depth to the overall experience.

Overview:
Escape Simulator offers a captivating and challenging escape room experience. Its strengths lie in the intricate puzzles, realistic environments, and cooperative gameplay. While it could benefit from a stronger narrative element and occasional technical hiccups, these minor drawbacks are outweighed by the game's overall quality.

Gameplay:
The core gameplay revolves around solving a series of puzzles within a limited time frame to "escape" from a room or scenario. These puzzles range from classic lock-and-key combinations to more intricate riddles and logic challenges. The controls are intuitive, allowing for seamless interaction with objects. The inclusion of a multiplayer mode adds an exciting dimension, requiring effective communication and teamwork to succeed. Unique features like hidden compartments and interactive objects further enhance the gameplay experience.

Graphics and Sound:
Escape Simulator impresses with its detailed and immersive environments. From the subtle flicker of candlelight to the creaking of wooden floorboards, the game's sound design contributes significantly to the overall atmosphere. While not groundbreaking, the graphics are more than sufficient for the genre, focusing on creating realistic settings rather than pushing technical boundaries.

Story and Narrative:
The game's narrative takes a backseat to the puzzle-solving aspect. While there's a loose premise for each scenario, it serves primarily as a backdrop for the challenges at hand. A more robust and integrated storyline could elevate the overall experience, providing additional motivation for players to progress.

Performance and Technical Issues:
Escape Simulator runs smoothly for the most part, with load times being reasonable. While there were occasional minor technical hiccups, they were infrequent and didn't significantly hinder gameplay. The game demonstrates a level of polish that suggests a dedicated approach to addressing potential bugs.

Multiplayer and Community:
The multiplayer feature is a standout aspect of Escape Simulator. It promotes teamwork and cooperation, elevating the gameplay experience to a new level. The option to tackle puzzles with friends or engage with the community adds significant replay value.

Final Thoughts:
Escape Simulator delivers an engaging escape room experience that excels in its puzzles, realistic environments, and cooperative gameplay. Despite minor areas for improvement, such as narrative integration and occasional technical issues, the game's strengths far outweigh its drawbacks. For fans of the genre or anyone seeking a mentally stimulating challenge, Escape Simulator comes highly recommended.

This game nails a gap in the market. The ability to have an easy foundation to play, make, and share escape rooms.

Escape Simulator is similar to real-life escape rooms. You are typically given a theme and number of tasks and puzzles to complete in order to escape, these can vary in difficulty and style but ultimately follow the same formula in progression. Escape Simulator gives you a generous offering of pre-made ones by the team which definitely hit that conventional mark.

What makes this game miles ahead of the competition is the ability for players to make their own rooms, using the assets of the game but also their own assets as well. A fantastic combination which allows a extremely wonderful variety of puzzles which will be to everyone's liking. Whilst it may not have the polish you'd want to get immersed the creativity of the community really sells this and gives countless hours of fun.

The premise is simple: you can pick up objects, manipulate, investigate, move stuff around to solve the puzzles that will lead to you escaping the room. Puzzles can vary from very simple to myst-level complication, but for the most part are quite logical if you can piece the clues together that you find.

Id say the dev-made levels are fairly fun but easy, but this is one of those games you get for the community-made content. The level crafting is pretty robust and the creative community has crafted literally thousands of rooms to play and puzzle with, and unlike the rooms that come with the game, these can be QUITE challenging. Best enjoyed with friends, this is a very easy recommend for fun MP puzzling!

I loved playing this game so freaking much, But the new versus mode was not what I was expecting. It felt like I was just brute forcing my way through rooms instead of actually solving anything. The puzzles in the regular portion of the game have you read your surroundings and figure out what you are supposed to do, WHICH IS AMAZING FOR AN ESCAPE ROOM GAME. On the other hand you have the Versus mode which throws that logic out of the window faster than the flash movie flopped. Instead having you brute force your way and "solve" for some convoluted "puzzle" that just makes you repeat your mistakes over and over and just hope you get the right answer. I was wanting to race my friend to see who would be able to do an actual escape room (like the davinci code, or even the santas workshop). Not what I was expecting for the new update, but the regular mode is fun. Just dont play the new Versus mode.

[b]Puzzles[/b]
Brain. Hurts. But, to be honest, the puzzles are well-made and after completing the whole level, you'll feel like a freaking Einstein.

You need friends to play co-op. 0/10.

There are around 25 maps in the base game, some in DLCs and a lot of community-made ones. I think it's enough even for puzzle-lovers.
[b]Conclusion[/b]
Escape Simulator is a really cool puzzle game with hours of content. If you can use your brain longer than 1 minute, you definitely should try it. But I'd recommend you to buy it, when it's on sale.

I am recommending the game if you are interested in escape rooms, it is definitely worth the money. 

WHAT I LIKE:
- Nice art.
- Easy to understand mechanics.
- There are 27 escape rooms in total in the basic version, 4 more in each of the DLCs. You are looking at >10 hours of fun. - - Additionally, there are many community built rooms (and you can also build some yourself).
- The vast majority of puzzles are intuitive enough that you can figure them out without help. They are also clever and interesting, with different themes.
- Hints on how to proceed are provided if you do get stuck. 

WHAT I DISLIKE:
- Some, though thankfully only few, puzzles are too unintuitive and I would never have thought of the solution without using the hint. Like, there is absolutely no reason for me to think about breaking down a bar of soap to look for a pin inside.
- The tropheys. Each room has a time limit and if you can get out fast enough, you get a trophey. May seem like a good idea, but I find that it pushes me to use hints more than I would otherwise, to proceed faster and get the trophey first time. If you do not get it first time, you have to replay it (my completionist mind cannot NOT get the trophey if it's there). However, the rooms are not very replayable in short succession. Nothing is procedurally generated, every code is exactly the same, so replaying is a matter of a few minutes. Therefore, I don't really understand the point of the trophey. I would rather have a trophey for not using any hints, to motivate me to take my time and think.
- The tokens. Each room has 8 tokens hidden around it. Not really a bad idea, I like this type of thing, but not if it is nigh impossible to find. They are hidden too well. Despite consciously looking everywhere, I can rarely find more than 4 of them! It just gets frustrating. You have to be really stubborn and motivated to search for them all without resorting to guides. I wish the tokens were more conspicuous, bright coloured or sth. It would still be fairly hard to find them all, but not frustratingly so.
VERY FUN...

Me and my boyfriend were looking for something new to play together when we came across Escape Simulator. It happened to be on sale at the time, so we decided to try it out. It ended up being super awesome, so we went back and purchased the DLC's as well. While this game can absolutely be enjoyed alone, I find it much more enjoyable to work together and solve puzzles together. We were super excited to see community rooms because the game is rather short and can be finished within a few days without the addition of the community rooms. The game is super interactive, from being able to break pots, push buttons and levers, move decor such as pillows etc. The base game puzzles are super fun and there are 8 levels per room and there are about 5 rooms. All of the community rooms are well put together and some are incredibly intricate and can take a few hours to solve. All in all, this is a fantastic game, and if you're looking for something to bond with your partner or even friends, this is a great game for that, it requires communication, group problem solving and patience. 10/10 game def worth the money

This is hands-down the best escape-room-simulator around.  As an engine the interface is nice to use, and other than some early finnickyness having friends join that seems to be fixed now, everything works really well.

The included rooms are nicely polished, but the community rooms are where this game stands out.  While categorization could still use some work (the number of "15-minute, single-player" rooms that really aren't...), the makers have made it easy for creators to have their rooms available, and easy for players to download, rate, and provide feedback on those rooms.

Great puzzle game and a steady stream of quality content from both the developers and the community.

What a fantastic puzzle game! But it is important to realize that there is no save state for your rooms--at least in solo mode. So if you start and can't finish, the room resets. If you know that beforehand, I didn't! :D 

I played this entirely solo and it was very enjoyable to figure out each part of the puzzles. Working with a team would be faster (typically) yet it would likely also be frustrating and hilarious at times. Plus for me, it's be like someone telling you where to move your cards in Solitaire (irritating most of the time)

BUT, the extra eyes/brains should help on the more difficult challenges. For my part, I  found myself sometimes being overly literal with a clue or getting stuck in a "thinking loop"and would have benefited greatly from a different viewpoint. However the hints they provided were quite useful when I was completely stuck on a couple levels. 

Overall there's enough of a challenge in most of the rooms (especially as you get further along to put your brain to use for a good period of time. The physics are great and the ability to interact with almost everything is fun. (There's nothing quite like grinding to a halt in the saloon and throwing some bottles at the wall to alleviate the frustration!) 

I haven't found all the tokens (those things can be VERY well hidden) but I don't think I'm going to go back and grind for them. While it certainly would add more playtime with this title and a chance to carefully scour every single detail of each environment--and the environments are absolutely STUNNING!--it would likely be a pretty painful grind. Maybe in the future?

Regardless, this game is well worth the money as the puzzles are solid. Bonus points for the amazingly thought out and intricate levels.

-If I could have given this game a middle-of-the-road, I would have.-
One of the main issues that I found plaguing Escape Simulator is the fiddliness of its controls and the overwhelming inventory system. While the controls themselves are responsive, the design choice to include an inventory where players can store every minuscule item becomes more of a hindrance than a helpful feature. It often leads to a situation where one player can monopolize the room, hoarding every object in sight and leaving others with limited opportunities to engage with the puzzles. This creates confusion and forces players to sift through each item individually, slowing down progress and impeding the overall enjoyment of the game.
The abundance of trivial objects in the inventory adds unnecessary complexity, distracting players from the core puzzles and challenges. Instead of focusing on the main objectives, players find themselves entangled in a web of insignificant items, making it harder to discern which objects are truly crucial to their escape. Streamlining the inventory system and reducing the number of trivial items would alleviate the confusion, enabling players to stay focused on the essential elements of the game.
While the intention behind the inventory system may have been to enhance immersion and provide a sense of realism, it ultimately disrupts the gameplay flow and hampers the cooperative aspect of the game. By limiting the inventory to key items or relevant clues, the game would foster better collaboration among players, allowing everyone to actively participate in the escape experience.
Considering the Shift to VR: Given the challenges posed by fiddly controls and the inventory overload, it's worth exploring how Escape Simulator might benefit from a transition to virtual reality (VR). In a VR environment, the physical interactions and intuitive gestures would offer a more seamless and immersive experience. Players could physically explore the room, manipulate objects with their hands, and interact with the environment more naturally. This would eliminate the need for an extensive inventory system, as players could directly interact with the objects in the virtual space. Such a shift would promote a more balanced and engaging gameplay experience, alleviating the frustrations caused by the current control and inventory design.
Conclusion: Escape Simulator presents an intriguing escape room adventure, but its fiddly controls and overwhelming inventory system hinder the overall enjoyment and cooperative dynamics of the game. The tendency for one player to hoard every item in the room causes confusion and slows down progress for others, distracting from the core puzzles. By streamlining the inventory and focusing on key items, the game would benefit from improved collaboration and clearer objectives. Additionally, considering a transition to virtual reality (VR) could offer a more immersive and intuitive gameplay experience, allowing players to interact with the environment directly. By addressing these concerns and exploring new avenues, Escape Simulator could elevate its appeal and provide a more enjoyable escape room adventure for all players involved.

[h1]Great for single player escape room experience[/h1]

First, let me clarify that I have only played Escape Simulator in Solo Mode. And that mode is extremely fun. You get to do what is necessary in any escape room. Explore, observe, deduct, combine, and solve enough puzzles to escape.
Most puzzles are solveable with time while others require some help. But luckily, help is always available by pressing a help button. And so far, I have not been unable to solve a room and the help provided was always good enough when I was stuck.
So, if you like escape rooms, this game is for you!

[b]However[/b], I suspect that the Co-Op Mode might not work as well. The rooms in the main game are simply too small, as has been pointed out by others. Then again, rooms in the DLCs and community rooms are bigger and might work in Co-Op Mode.

All in all, a great game and worth its price, especially when it is on sale.

[u]Disclaimer[/u]:
I didn‚Äôt try this in single player, I bought this game to play in two player co-op, based on the store page description "[i]best with 2-3 players, but playable with more[/i]" as the main reason.

[hr][/hr] 
[h2]I like puzzle games, I like co-op games and I really like co-op puzzle games, but unfortunately Escape Simulator fails in that department.[/h2]


For comparison, we can take a look at ‚ÄòWe Were Here‚Äô as an example for a game that does co-op well.
‚ÄòWe Were Here‚Äô is designed for two players in mind, putting each player in a completely different environment, giving them different tools and providing each of them with only half of the solution to the puzzle, forcing them to communicate and cooperate in order to win.


In contrast, Escape Simulator seems to be designed for a single player with only minimal changes when playing in co-op;
Each map is very small, claustrophobic and filled with many interact-able objects which you can pick up, and since each player can pick up things and store them in their inventory or throw them around (some of which can even break into many smaller pieces) it creates chaos and confusion as each player is looking at a different direction and is unaware of the actions of the other.

[hr][/hr] 

[h2]When both players are in the same room it means you really only need one player to actually solve the puzzle and the other player is just in the way by blocking the view or interacting with objects.[/h2]


The only difference between solo and co-op is that some puzzles change slightly to force two players to interact with them simultaneously.
For example in one of the rooms you need to adjust the position of 2 levers, when in single player you can just freely move them but when playing co-op the levers don‚Äôt hold their position so both players have to hold them.


That‚Äôs it, that's all that makes this a ‚Äúco-op game, best with 2-3 players‚Äù.


The game ends up being worse in co-op than just having one player stream it to the other while playing solo, because what‚Äôs the point of having two or more (I can‚Äôt even imagine what a nightmare this would be with more) players if they are both looking and interacting with the same stuff anyway.


I do wanna note some features that I did like, although most of them just make the game better for solo play:
[list]
[*]The way you can pick up and throw items feels pretty nice.
[*]You can inspect and pin items to your screen (useful for notes etc.) and then move them around (though you can‚Äôt resize them, and some have bad textures making it hard to read as it is).
[*]When a player is inspecting an item other players can join in and inspect it with them, with the caveat that while they can interact with things like buttons and dials, only the person holding the item can rotate and if he stops inspecting the other player gets booted out of it.
[*]Also worth noting about the above points, when inspecting, the game seems to take a snapshot of the screen and blur the background so you can‚Äôt actually see what‚Äôs happening in front of you (this caused some annoying situations and miscommunications until we figured that out). And more importantly, some items can‚Äôt be viewed properly when ‚Äúguest inspecting‚Äù, when my friend inspected a remote control camera it worked fine for him but when I tried to watch what he was doing I just saw the camera rotating infinitely (which again caused some confusion) and I have no idea how that‚Äôs acceptable for the developers in a multiplayer game.
[/list]


I think this game might be decent enough solo, but if you‚Äôre looking for a good co-op experience you should keep looking.

The community maps, and friends make this game a great time.

The movement/controls of this game, as well as the game mechanics in general, are so far superior to most other digital escape games that it is almost laughable. The steam workshop support takes this game from great straight to fantastic. The *only* place this game can improve would be with a save feature for in-progress levels - although most of the official levels will take between 10-20 minutes, some of the steam workshop levels can take close to an hour, which is great, but not so great if you can't play them in one setting. Likewise, it would be useful if the workshop levels displayed the average (outliers excluded) time players took to complete the level - not so much for trying to beat that time, but more to give you an idea of what you're getting into before you start considering the lack of consistency in the length of workshop levels.

A great casual game. The core levels form a nice collection of 3d room-escape mini-games, most of which belong in one of a few themed series. The music and graphics are excellent, and the puzzles are very good as I recall. New free levels are added from time to time (there are also a couple of DLCs you can buy, but I don't have those so I'm only reviewing the main game). In case you're ever stuck in the standard levels, on YouTube there are walkthroughs for everything (including collectibles and achievements).

However, Escape Simulator's greatest strength is in the community. You can play with your friends, you can make your own levels with the level editor and share them with the world, and you can play other people's levels. There are scores of player-made levels, along with curated monthly and yearly collections thereof (and also frequent level-creation competitions). This is what will keep you coming back to the game. You can even find walkthroughs for some popular player-made levels.

The control scheme combines keyboard and mouse controls (touchpad is not recommended), and it's a little clunky at times. It's possible (though uncommon) for an item to disappear behind a wall, but I've found that this isn't a big deal. What really needs some work in my opinion is the multiplayer setup; if you lose connection for even a moment, you can't rejoin the group, and this does spoil the fun when it happens.

Despite the aforementioned problems, this is an overall fun game to enjoy with friends, and I'm glad I bought it. If you like room-escape games, I think you too will become a fan.

Really good puzzles on the main campaigns, kudos to the designers. Always a good level of challenge without feeling too hard or frustrating and handy clue options if you do get stuck. The bonus hidden tokens make for decent replayability as well. Only complaint is that there are just not enough of the main levels, but more to come soon I guess! Once you have finished all the main levels, there are also lots of really good rooms from the community workshop, so always plenty of good content available as well. Interface is not too bad either, though room for improvement. Mainly the fact that once you fill it past the first 9 items you can't access items at the end until you clear out some stuff, but this is no biggie for me really.
All in all, a really enjoyable way to exercise the brain muscles and even more fun with a friend or two to help. I highly recommend most of the co-op workshop rooms if you really want to test your communication skills with a friend :)

Escape Simulator: A Thrilling Escape Room Adventure!

Escape Simulator is a thrilling game that takes the excitement of real-life escape rooms and brings it to the virtual world. With its immersive puzzles, challenging scenarios, and engaging gameplay, it's a must-play for escape room enthusiasts and puzzle lovers.

The game puts your problem-solving skills to the test as you navigate through a variety of cleverly designed rooms. Each room presents a unique set of challenges, requiring you to search for clues, solve puzzles, and think outside the box to escape within the time limit.

The attention to detail in Escape Simulator is impressive, with intricate puzzles that will have you scratching your head and feeling a rush of satisfaction when you finally crack them. The immersive environments and atmospheric sound effects further enhance the experience, drawing you into the world of each escape room.

Whether you're playing solo or with friends, Escape Simulator offers an enjoyable and challenging experience. The game provides a great balance between difficulty and fun, making it accessible for both beginners and seasoned escape room veterans.

If you're a fan of escape rooms or simply love solving puzzles, Escape Simulator is a fantastic choice. It provides the thrill and satisfaction of real-life escape rooms from the comfort of your own home. So get ready to put your problem-solving skills to the test and embark on an unforgettable virtual escape room adventure!

The puzzles actually make you think really hard, and the feeling of satisfaction you get after solving one is immense. Although sometimes it can be a bit disorienting as there is simply so much variety in the types of puzzles, advancing through the rooms always makes you feel completely lost initially. The puzzles are also very context driven, and align themselves well with the theme of the room. I love the little details left about in each room that make you wonder about the backstories. The only complaint I might have is that the coop could perhaps be better? As it is, you could easily solve each room solo, and the coop mode does not seem to add any coop element to it other than simply 2 people solving it at the same time. It might be fun to have certain rooms that require the cooperation of 2 or more individuals to solve. Does not take away from the immersive-ness but would be a great addition to have. Other than that, absolutely a must buy if you enjoy scratching your head over very well crafted puzzles with an excellent playtime. Secret tokens are hella hard to find though...

Are you tired of your mundane life and want to experience the thrill of a prison escape? Then Escape Simulator is the game for you! This simulator game is perfect for anyone who loves the idea of breaking out of prison without actually having to go to jail.

The graphics in Escape Simulator are‚Ä¶ well, let's just say they're not going to win any awards. The prison looks like it was designed by a 5-year-old with a crayon, and the guards are about as intelligent as a loaf of bread. But hey, who needs fancy graphics when you're plotting your escape?

One of the best things about Escape Simulator is the variety of escape routes you can take. From crawling through air vents to digging tunnels with spoons, there's a prison break method for every occasion. And let's be honest, who doesn't love a good heist movie?

Another great feature of Escape Simulator is the ability to customize your character. You can choose your inmate's hairstyle, clothing, and even their tattoo. Just be careful not to make them too memorable, or the guards might catch on to your plan.

Of course, no game is perfect. Escape Simulator does have its fair share of quirks and annoyances. Sometimes the guards will spot you even if you're hiding behind a lamp, or your character will glitch through the wall and get stuck in the ceiling. But hey, that just adds to the challenge, right?

Overall, if you're looking for a game that's equal parts thrilling and ridiculous, then Escape Simulator is definitely worth a try. Just be prepared to spend hours planning your escape and to laugh at the absurdity of it all.

Game has lots of potential but lack of polish.

I immediately noticed the inventory UX is fighting against me. Clicking both mouse buttons and spacebar to do stuff that could be done with one button. I may need to learn more shortcuts if they exist, but I can't deal with 3 buttons to do the same kind of stuff. 

Changing video settings didn't apply. I found no apply button. Found no evidence my video settings changed. No feedback from the program when I changed settings.

It's easier to put items in bins than it is to take them out. (1 click = bin, 2 clicks + a right click = back in inventory)

Scrollwheel up doesn't select items at first, you have to scroll down first. 

The question mark button on the wall should be nixed and a question mark or a camera in your inventory would be better. The wall button breaks the immersion of being stuck somewhere. It also too-closely resembles a Mario Block question mark. Looking at it on the wall, I feel like I'm on a game show. 

Investigating items is a pain. Unlike THE ROOM, there's no contextual hints when clicking on something incorrectly. Stuff like "There's no water in the canteen, but I can see something inside..." would be great. I spent a minute trying to angle the canteen so the coin would line-up, but the camera angle was fixed so I couldn't look top-down into it. 

LOTS of extra crap in the room to pickup. They put a garbage bin in the room so you can organize, which IMHO is a problem failing to solve another problem. Escape rooms should only have less distracting items.

Maybe an option to give more time to solo adventurers. 

The very first room has a book you need to reference to solve a puzzle. Standard escape room stuff. The background symbols you are referencing blurs out, and the book covers your entire face. Leaving you some choices. Run down the timer and compare, don't play solo, or break the immersion and screenshot it. I don't want to do any of those things to solve a puzzle. I noticed the Timer was running down as I looked back and forth from the book 10+ times and I said screw it, I'm writing a review because the UX of the solo play is not up to my standard. 

Room look and quantity are spoiled for you when you look at the main menu. Think of older games where they would only show you the levels you made it to? The menu sorely needs that. Give users something they want to work towards instead of showing them everything they can possibly do. This way it feels more like a game and less of a sandbox.  

I'll go back and try again, and I'll eagerly await updates, but as a HUGE fan of point and clicks, escape rooms, I see this game being better, and my first impression wasn't anywhere near the smooth as the UX from THE ROOM. 

Still marking as recommended because there's nothing else like it and it has huge potential.

I'd highly suggest the the community rooms devilish diorama and devilish diorama 2. Honestly they are in my top 5 favorite escape experiences to date.

In short, I would highly recommend this game if you're into escape rooms and/or puzzler type games.  To be completely transparent, I bought this game on sale when it was a few dollars off about a month back, but it allowed me to purchase all of the discounted DLC as well, but even at full price, you really do get a lot for your money - even without the added DLC.  

I frequent escape rooms  in the real world.  I've never done any virtual escape rooms so I'm not exactly sure how this game would compare to an experience like that, but I've thoroughly enjoyed stimulating my brain and taking a break from the mainstream types of games like shooters and RPG's with this gem.  I initially exhausted all of the free to play options for escape room games on steam, and some were decent whereas others weren't that great, but as to be expected especially considering the price (none).

I can honestly say that when it came time to spending money on an escape game, there are a few that stood out to me and that I still have on my wishlist to eventually pick up, but Escape Simulator seemed to have the most going for it in that the BASE game has over 20 different escape rooms across 4 entirely different themes - each with their own aesthetic and puzzle types - not to mention the versatility of community rooms and an editor that you can use to create your own.  The fact that the team at Pine Studios consistently curates their top picks for the previous month makes everything feel new and will keep me coming back even after fully completing this game.  They also have been known to add free DLC rooms, like their newest: Leonardo's Workshop, which is a room full of many puzzles and gives you upwards of an hour to escape versus the standard 15 minutes.

The Steampunk & Wild West DLC, especially if you can get on sale, would come highly recommended by me as well.  Each consists of four separate rooms, again, fitting the overall "chapter" or "series" of rooms, but completely unique from eachother.  These rooms also have an escape time of 45 minutes, meaning more puzzles and more fun to work your way through - worth every penny! 

I didn't find many of the puzzles to be overly complicated throughout my play, although they weren't particularly easy either.  I found there to be a great mix of general logic puzzles as well as your standard lock/key/combinations, which typically I'm more a fan of the latter.  It feels very rewarding to complete a room and finish it with seconds or minutes to spare to secure the trophy over the participation ribbon!

Another great feature that I found works seamlessly, aside from a few laggy connection issues, is the ability to play co-op as easily as you can play solo.  Playing co-op with your friends, or even finding some in the active community on Steam or Pine Studio's Discord, presents a different element and sometimes a completely different challenge in itself.  Communication is key, and I definitely found solo play easier since YOU'RE the one with access to all of the clues and information.  There is so much to pick up and inspect in each of these rooms, and not all of the "props" have a purpose so things can get cluttered at times - especially factoring in the ability to break different items around the room.  It was a very good idea for them to add a garbage can to let you clean up as you go and keep things simple and organized.

The inventory system is great, too.  Although it's unlimited and in theory, you could hold on to everything you find in the room, I found that once you're at over 9 items, the hot keys become a real pain to use and the controls suddenly feel very clunky.

The tokens, although a fun little tidbit as seemingly every game needs to have some sort of collectable these days, don't do anything.  One of my only negatives for this game would be that there should be some incentive to collecting these aside from the achievement at the end.  Don't get me wrong, I did it, but I didn't enjoy it.  It would be cool if maybe it unlocked some unique appearance options since they spent at least a little time with allowing you to customise your character.

Again, all-in-all, TL;DR:  If you're into escape room games in real life and haven't tried any video games of this style, you can't go wrong with this one.  If, like me, you started with trying some free escape room games, I can't recommend Escape Simulator high enough as the first one to spend money on as the few naggy negatives I have about this game really don't pertain to the core of what it is at all.  You won't be disappointed, especially if you like these types of games!

As a final note, and partially why I was able to spend nearly 50 hours on this game is because I enjoyed it so much, I put together some short guides on how to solve some of the most complex puzzles in each of the rooms - as well as full room walkthroughs for each of the rooms available currently, with the exception of community rooms.  If you want to "try before you buy" or if you're needing some help after using your last hint, check out our [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLhvfmPNrUktl-cTVstl3ojs7ya5cw1MMj] Friendly Frenzy Games YouTube channel! [/url]

I initially thought this would be a snooze, however it has turned out to be a wonderful game and surprisingly one of the few that my wife really enjoys. Although it can be done solo, I think it is primarily a co-op game as doing it with friends is great. I recommend only 2-3 play together though, we tried it with 5 and although it worked we tended to get lost as others would solve puzzles before some even got to see them.

The game gives you some basic tools - look around, pick something up, move something, etc. and dumps you into a room filled with puzzles - if you have ever done an escape room or wanted to, give this a try as it simulates the kind of things in them pretty well.  There are a couple of issues with the engine - default movement tends to make me nauseous (there are some montio-sickness options which help) and sometimes things that are dropped go through the floor and are lost..but by and large it runs without problem on my computer.

The puzzles can be tricky - counting the footprints in the room gives the code to unlock the door, or finding a well hidden number in a painting on the wall, etc. But by and large they are sensible and fun. Plus everyone has hints or a walkthrough available if you get stumped.

What really shines is the Workshop. Dozens/hundreds of homemade escape rooms being created by devious minds and programmed into the game. It means it will never get boring for as long as you want to play it.

I recommend getting someone you know who is reluctant to play games (boyfriend/girlfriend/mom/etc.) to give it a try, it can really hook people who don't care for traditional games, and as a bonus if they are interested in game creation, there is the workshop which gives you all the tools you need to make your own and share them with the world.

Escape Simulator is a very intricate and challenging game that will keep you on the edge of your intellectual abilities and strategic thinking. The game focuses on teamwork and communication, making it a great way to enjoy time with friends.

Players find themselves in different rooms full of puzzles, riddles and hidden keys that they must find and use to escape. Each room has its own unique solution, meaning players must use their creativity and work together to get out.

One of the biggest benefits of this game is that it can be played with friends. Together you can share ideas, plan strategy and work together to get out. This makes the game even more fun and intense because you have to interact with other players and work together to achieve a common goal.

Although Escape Simulator is very convoluted and challenging, it is a great game for those who love puzzles and mysterious rooms. I recommend this game to anyone who wants to enjoy challenging and fun gameplay with friends.

Escape Simulator! And boy, oh boy, did my friends Moe and Julian and I have a wild time playing it. We were so drunk, we probably should have been trying to escape a bar, but no, we were in our own virtual world of escape.

Let me start by saying that this game is the perfect mix of hilarious and challenging. It's like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube while being chased by a pack of wild dogs. But instead of dogs, you're being chased by crazy obstacles and traps that make you laugh and scream at the same time.

Moe, Julian, and I were so immersed in the game that we forgot we were just sitting in front of our computers. We were yelling and cheering as if we were actually trying to escape from a prison or a haunted house. And trust me, it's not easy to solve puzzles and escape rooms while being drunk, but we managed to do it somehow.

The best part of the game was the hilarious voiceovers and dialogue that kept us laughing throughout. We couldn't stop quoting lines like "I'm too pretty to die" or "I'm too dumb for this" for days after we played. And let's not forget about the random fart noises that had us rolling on the floor.

Overall, Escape Simulator is the perfect game for a night of drunken shenanigans with your friends. It's challenging enough to keep you engaged, but funny enough to keep you laughing until your stomach hurts. So, if you're looking for a game that will make you forget your problems and have a great time, Escape Simulator is the way to go!

I like "real life" escape rooms and I really enjoyed Escape Simulator. I haven't played other escape games yet, but this one is fun and well crafted. The graphics are rather simple, but have decent details sufficient for this genre. The music or rather musical background is also very simplistic but again works well with the different themes. I think the strongest sides of the game are the creative rooms, especially the newer ones and the excellent multiplayer which just works without issues. The game mechanics and interaction can be clumsy at times but does the job and the physics are a source of fun for those who like to wreak havoc :). It is a nice substitute and/or extension for a real life escape experience  and I can strongly recommend.

I wasn't sure how this game would be. Sometimes escape games are so obtuse with their solutions that it feels more like guess and check than deduction. Other times they are so easy that it's kind of a waste of time. However, this game really hits the sweet spot. It is challenging, but has nice puzzles which you can reason your way through. The puzzles are each bite-size enough to play one or two in a sitting without requiring a huge time commitment. It can be done alone, which would probably be quite tough to do (within the time limit), but it is a blast to play with friends in online co-op. You can even have some people sit with you while you play and provide suggestions or ideas to include friends, family, spouse, etc. in the game even if they aren't really into games.

If you enjoy puzzle games and/or real world escape rooms, I definitely recommend this game.
